ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: Microwave-induced high surface functionalization of multi-walled carbon nanotubes for long-term dispersion in water

Affiliation.OrgDivision: Chemical Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: Multi-walled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs) were functionalized by monoethanolamine (MEA), diethanolamine (DEA) and triethanolamine (TEA) by a rapid microwave-assisted method. Surface functional groups and morphology of MWCNTs were analyzed by ultraviolet-visible spectroscopy, Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy, thermogravimetric analysis, Raman spectroscopy and transmission electron microscopy. The water dispersibility of samples was also measured over time and compared with that of MWCNT functionalized by ethylenediamine (EDA). Accordingly, the dispersibility was in the sequence MEA-MWCNTs > DEA-MWCNTs > TEA-MWCNTs > EDA-MWCNTs > pristine MWCNTs. The significant long-term dispersibility of MEA-MWCNTs was related to its exceptionally high surface functionalization (89.3 %) and lack of chemical bridging between adjacent MWCNTs. This strategy, along with the low-cost functionalizing agents, could pave the way for large-scale dispersion of CNTs in the polar solvents.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: The unique mechanical [1, 2], electrical [3] and thermal [4] properties of carbon nanotubes (CNTs) have attracted considerable research attention, turning them to ideal candidates for various applications, such as chemical and biochemical sensors [5, 6], high-performance composites [7], high thermal transport nanofluids [8] and drug delivery agents [9]. Nonetheless, these applications are mostly hindered by the weak reactivity and dispersibility of CNTs [10]. For instance, to use the desirable thermal properties of CNTs in nanofluid, they have to be dispersed in water. However, CNTs normally tend to agglomerate in solvents [11].

Therefore, it is not surprise that considerable efforts have been devoted to modification of CNTs to improve their dispersibility [12]. Oxidative cutting of CNTs was known to improve their dispersibility, due to incorporated carboxylic acid functionality on the nanotube surface. For instance, Rosca et al. [13] reached a high dispersibility (20 mg/ml) for MWCNTs treated for 24 h in concentrated HNO3. However, this treatment was revealed to diminish 60 % of the MWCNTs, imposing significant defects on the graphitic sidewalls of CNTs. So, a milder/faster functionalization is required for dispersing purposes.

Among the various functional groups capable of attaching CNTs, amine groups seem to be more widespread, due to their relatively facile and environmentally-benign process [14, 15]. Zhou et al. [16] functionalized the MWCNTs with ethylenediamine (EDA) by a simple and solvent-free process based on stirring and heating for 10 hours. Wang et al. [17] expedited the synthesis of the amine-functionalized single-walled carbon nanotubes (SWCNTs) to 15 minutes by means of microwave radiation, without noticeable difference in functionalization to what was achieved in 5 days using the conventional methods.

A recent study around microwave-assisted functionalization of CNTs with different amines suggested that small molecules like EDA are more efficient in CNT functionalization [18]. However, EDA-functionalized CNT has no significant dispersibility in water. This originates from the fact that EDA could eventually react from its both amine groups, resulting in linkage between adjacent CNTs, and so lowering the CNT dispersibility [18, 19]. To avoid such linkage and still take benefit of EDA chemistry, one may exchange EDA with a similar molecule. Ethanolamines (EAs) resemble EDA structure, unless they have just one amine group, limiting the chance for linking adjacent CNTs. These materials are also almost inexpensive, leading to the cost-effective dispersing of CNTs. To the best of our knowledge, no report has been published on the functionalization of CNTs with EAs.

Here, multi-walled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs) are functionalized by monoethanolamine (MEA), diethanolamine (DEA) and triethanolamine (TEA) using a fast microwave method. To maximize the probability of functionalization, the conditions were provided for coexistence of all three probable reactions: esterification, amidation and electrophilic addition. This strategy could lead to a high degree of functionalization and eventually a fast and cost-effective process. This fact, along with the low-cost functionalizing agents (such as EAs), may lead to a large-scale process for CNT dispersion, needed by composite and cooling industries.

Section2.Heading: Materials
Section2.Para: The pristine MWCNTs synthesized by chemical vapor deposition (diameter 10–20 nm, length 5–15 μm and purity >95 %) were obtained from Shenzhen Nano-Tech Port Co. Mono-, di- and tri-ethanolamine, aluminum chloride, sodium nitrite, hydrochloric acid, nitric acid, sulfuric acid, N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) and thionyl chloride, all with analytical grade, were purchased from Merck. PTFE filtration membranes (pore size of 0.2 μm) were also acquired from Whatman Co.

Section2.Heading: Functionalization of MWCNTs
Section2.Para:
Amine functionality was shown to play role in CNT functionalization via amidation and esterification mechanisms [20, 21], while alcohols are known to be effective via electrophilic addition reaction [22, 23]. Obviously, EAs have both amine and alcoholic groups; so, all the above reactions may coexist for them. Figure 1 shows the expected mechanisms for functionalization of MWCNTs with MEA, DEA and TEA (MEA-, DEA- and TEA-MWCNT).
Fig. 1
The anticipated mechanisms for functionalization of MWCNTs with MEA, DEA and TEA. X stands for –H, or –C2H4OH, wherever applicable. It should be noted that AlCl3 as a Lewis acid and also water-absorbent can catalyze all three reactions

Accordingly, the pristine MWCNTs (150 mg), sulfuric acid (15 ml) and nitric acid (45 ml) were added to a dry 100 ml flask and stirred for 12 h by a magnetic stirrer at room temperature to produce oxidized MWCNTs. Such procedure is known to introduce carboxyl groups (–COOH/–COO–) on the surface of the MWCNTs [24, 25]. The mixture was then filtered through a PTFE membrane. The resultant filter cake was washed several times using de-ionized water until the pH value reached 6 and then dried at 50 °C for 24 h. The acid-MWCNTs (150 mg) were mixed with an excess of AlCl3 (1 g) and ground for around 5 min in an agate mortar.

This mixture was then transferred into a vessel filled with 30 ml DMF as well as 15 ml of intended EA and sonicated for 10 min at 50 °C, until a homogeneous suspension was obtained. Then, 0.5 ml concentrated HCl was added to the mixture and all placed in a home-made microwave oven (LG-4284TCR). The microwave magnetron was equipped with an electromagnetic relay switched on and off by a PID controller, in order to maintain constant temperature in the vessel. The suspension was heated for 15 min at 100 °C under irradiation power of 800 W. The reaction mixture was then filtered through a PTFE membrane. The resulting black solid was thoroughly washed with DMF and abundant de-ionized water to remove residues of unreacted excess reagents, and then dried overnight at 50 °C. The same procedure was performed for the functionalization of EDA, except that EDA was used without diluting with DMF. This sample was just synthesized for comparison of its dispersibility with other samples.

In order to evaluate the specific role of aforementioned mechanism, we synthesized DEA-MWCNTs by each of amidation, esterification and electrophilic addition mechanisms, such that the reaction was carried out just in one definite way. Procedures were performed based on the literature [22, 24, 25] with slight modification. The details of the synthesis procedure are presented in supplementary information (see Appendix).

Section2.Heading: Characterizations
Section2.Para: Ultraviolet–visible spectroscopy (UV-vis, AvaLight-DH-CAL) and Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR, Thermo-Nicolet Avatar 370) were used to study the functional groups attached to MWCNTs. To obtain UV-vis spectra, all samples were dispersed in distilled water by an ultrasound bath for 10 min, just before the analysis. The FTIR spectra were evaluated in the range of 400–4000 cm−1 and all samples were placed on KBr pellets.

The dispersibility of MWCNTs in distilled water was measured based on weighing sediments after different intended times (from 15 min to 1 month). Thermogravimetry analysis (TGA-50 Shimadzu) was also conducted in order to study quantitative amount of EA functionalization on MWCNTs. TGA experiments were carried out at heating rate of 10 °C/min in the dry air atmosphere. The corresponding weight losses of functional group and carbon were used to calculate the so-called func.CNT [18, 26] as well as CNTs coverage of the functional groups (CFG) (Eqs. (1) and (2), respectively). The latter is defined as the reciprocal of what previously was defined by Tian et al. [22]. The theoretical number of surface carbon atoms was calculated based on the geometry of studied MWCNTs.
1
$$\begin{aligned} &{\mathrm{func}.\mathrm{CNT} = \frac{\mathrm{Moles}\ \mathrm{of}\ \mathrm{functional}\ \mathrm{groups}}{ \mathrm{Moles}\ \mathrm{of}\ \mathrm{carbon}\ \mathrm{in}\ \mathrm{CNTs}}} \\ &{\phantom{\mathrm{func}.\mathrm{CNT}}= \frac{\frac{\mathrm{Mass}\ \mathrm{loss}\ \mathrm{of}\ \mathrm{functional}\ \mathrm{groups}}{\mathrm{Molecular}\ \mathrm{weight}\ \mathrm{of}\ \mathrm{functional}\ \mathrm{groups}}}{ \frac{\mathrm{Mass}\ \mathrm{loss}\ \mathrm{of}\ \mathrm{carbon}\ \mathrm{portion}\ \mathrm{of}\ \mathrm{CNTs}}{\mathrm{Molecular}\ \mathrm{weight}\ \mathrm{of}\ \mathrm{carbon}}}} \end{aligned}$$
2
$$\begin{aligned} &{\mathrm{CFG}\ (\%) = \frac{\mathrm{Moles}\ \mathrm{of}\ \mathrm{functional}\ \mathrm{groups}}{ \mathrm{Moles}\ \mathrm{of}\ \mathrm{carbon}\ \mathrm{on}\ \mathrm{the}\ \mathrm{surface}\ \mathrm{of}\ \mathrm{CNTs}}} \\ &{\phantom{\mathrm{CFG}\ (\%)=}{} \times 100~\% } \end{aligned}$$

A Bruker Senterra Raman microscope with 785-nm excitation laser at 50 mW was used to measure the Raman spectra in the range 144–3802 cm−1. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM, LEO 912 AB electron microscope) was also used to investigate morphology of the functionalized MWCNTs. The preparation of TEM samples includes sonication of MWCNTs in ethanol solution for 10 min.

Section2.Heading: Ultraviolet-visible spectroscopy
Section2.Para:
Figure 2 shows UV-vis spectra of MEA-, DEA- and TEA-MWCNTs compared to the pristine MWCNTs and corresponding aqueous solution of EAs. As could be seen in Fig. 2(a), the peaks at 222 and 306 nm are in compliance with MEA. The peak at 242 nm associated with pristine MWCNTs, slightly blue-shifted after functionalization. Similarly for the DEA- and TEA-MWCNTs, two peaks at 234 and 228 nm are associated with DEA and TEA and peaks at 248 and 239 nm may relate to pristine MWCNTs, respectively. Also, contrary to functionalized samples, the spectrum of the pristine MWCNTs has the characteristic van Hove singularities. Dramatic decrease of the van Hove singularities of functionalized samples suggests the heavy functionalization of MWCNTs with EAs [22, 27].
Fig. 2
UV-vis spectra of (a) MEA-MWCNTs, (b) DEA-MWCNTs and (c) TEA-MWCNTs compared to pristine MWCNTs and aqueous solution of EAs

Section2.Heading: Infrared spectroscopy
Section2.Para:
Infrared spectra of MEA-, DEA- and TEA-MWCNTs as well as pristine MWCNTs are shown in Fig. 3. The wide peak at the ranges of 3350–3500 cm−1 is well known for O–H groups, but one could observe the shoulders around 3430 and 2940 cm−1, representing N–H and C–H stretching vibrations [28]. The weak peaks at 1560 and 1460 cm−1 are also consistent to the N–H vibration and the asymmetric vibration of CH2, respectively. The stretching vibration at 1630 cm−1 is related to carbonyl groups and the peak at 1070 cm−1 is in agreement with the stretching vibration of C–O bond. All these peaks could confirm MWCNTs functionalization with EAs.
Fig. 3
FTIR spectra of the pristine MWCNTs, MEA-, DEA- and TEA-MWCNTs

As we know, TEA is not able to react with MWCNTs via amidation mechanism. So, its functionalization was done just by either esterification or electrophilic addition reaction. On the other hand, the observed OH group for the case of MEA-MWCNT shows that at least the esterification is not the sole functionalization mechanism there. So, one may conclude that different EAs do not react with MWCNTs via the same set of mechanisms. Moreover, at least two mechanisms coexist in all functionalized samples. Further researches may be done for exact elucidation of different functionalized moieties on the MWCNTs. Here, we focus on the resultant dispersibility and degree of functionalization.

Figure 4 shows the FTIR spectra of the DEA-MWCNTs with various functionalization mechanisms (named Am-DEA-MWCNT for amidation, Es-DEA-MWCNT for esterification and El-DEA-MWCNT for electrophilic addition mechanisms). Same as in Fig. 3, all the treated samples showed clear evidence of the attached chemical moieties.
Fig. 4
FTIR spectra of the Am-DEA-MWCNTs, Es-DEA-MWCNTs and El-DEA-MWCNTs

Section2.Heading: Dispersibility of the samples
Section2.Para:
The polar hydroxyl groups on EA-functionalized MWCNTs are anticipated to promote the MWCNT stability in a polar solvent like water [22]. Figure 5 shows dispersibility results of MWCNT samples in the distilled water versus time. While the pristine MWCNTs start aggregating shortly after sonication, the EA-functionalized MWCNTs have stable suspensions up to one month. Noteworthy, all the EA-functionalized MWCNTs show higher dispersibility than EDA-MWCTs, suggesting lack of bridging between MWCNTs. In a closer view, MEA- and DEA-MWCNTs retained stable suspension at higher concentration than TEA-MWCNTs, up to one month (Fig. 6). This implies the relatively higher coverage of functional groups on MEA- and DEA-MWCNTs.
Fig. 5
Dispersibility in distilled water vs. time for the pristine MWCNTs, EDA-, MEA-, DEA- and TEA-MWCNTs
Fig. 6
Optical photographs of the (a) pristine MWCNTs, (b) EDA-MWCNTs, (c) MEA-MWCNTs (d) DEA-MWCNTs and (e) TEA-MWCNTs in distilled water at a concentration of 1 mg/ml, taken after 30 days

As could be seen, the long-term dispersibility of MEA- and DEA-MWCNTs in de-ionized water was ∼1 mg/ml, higher than some best dispersibility values observed for MWCNTs functionalized by amines (1,6-hexanediamine, diethylenetriamine and triethylenetriamine) [14] and SWCNTs functionalized by ethanol [22]. However, our dispersibility is still lower than that of lysine-functionalized MWCNTs (10 mg/ml) produced in a prolonged stirring procedure [29].

The dispersion amounts of Am-DEA-MWCNT, Es-DEA-MWCNT and El-DEA-MWCNT are compared with DEA-MWCNT in Fig. 7. In comparison, DEA-MWCNT (0.95 mg/ml) retained stable in higher concentration than Am-DEA-MWCNT (0.71 mg/ml), Es-DEA-MWCNT (0.13 mg/ml) and El-DEA-MWCNT (0.02 mg/ml). So, one can conclude that the offered procedure is more effective than each of amidation, esterification and electrophilic addition mechanisms in increasing the surface-attached functional groups. This finding suggests that our offered procedure provides the condition for coexistence of 2–3 of these mentioned mechanisms.
Fig. 7
Dispersibility of the DEA-MWCNTs, Am-DEA-MWCNTs, Es-DEA-MWCNTs and El-DEA-MWCNTs in distilled water at a concentration of 1 mg/ml, after a week

Section2.Heading: Thermogravimetric analysis
Section2.Para:
Thermogravimetric analysis curve of the pristine MWCNTs, MEA-, DEA- and TEA-MWCNTs is shown in Fig. 8. While the TGA curve of pristine MWCNTs is steady without significant weight loss below 540 °C, the treated samples show a distinct weight loss in the temperature range of 140–500 °C. The weight loss of products can be attributed to decomposition of the functional moieties attached to the surface of MWCNTs [14].
Fig. 8
TGA analysis of the pristine MWCNTs, MEA-, DEA- and TEA-MWCNTs

The results of func.CNT and the CFG for the EA-functionalized MWCNTs are presented in Table 1. CFG values clearly reveal that MEA-MWCNTs are almost (89.3 %) fully covered with functional groups and DEA- and TEA-MWCNTs have significant coverages (46.6 and 10.4 %, respectively). To the best of our knowledge, the func.CNT values of MEA-MWCNTs are higher than what was previously reported for amine functionalization by Amiri et al. [18] (0.0983, 0.0401 and 0.0680 for ethylenediamine-, 1,6-hexamethylenediamine- and 1,4-diaminobenzene-MWCNTs, respectively) and for alcohol functionalization by Tian et al. [22] (0.0769 and 0.0323 for ethanol- and 1,2-ethanediol-SWCNTs, respectively).

Comparing both the CFG and func.CNT values of functionalized MWCNTs, it appears that the larger the reacting EA molecule, the lower functionalization yield and dispersibility for MWCNTs. It may be due to the steric hindrance of the larger molecules like TEA [30]. Moreover, since TEA cannot react with MWCNTs by amidation mechanism, it has a lower chance for attaching MWCNTs.

While MEA- and DEA-MWCNTs have shown a similar dispersibility, the latter has a predominantly lower coverage by functionalization reaction. This could be due to two polar hydroxyl groups in DEA structure, comparing with MEA.

Section2.Heading: Raman spectroscopy
Section2.Para:
Figure 9 shows the Raman spectra of both pristine and functionalized MWCNTs. The results present D and G bands, at 1550 and 1668 cm−1, respectively. The D band is associated with the amorphous/disordered carbon and the G band is related to crystalline graphitic carbon. Intensity ratios of D and G bands (I D/I G) are known to appraise the proportion of disordered (sp3) to graphitic (sp2) carbon. A higher I D/I G indicates greater disruption of C=C on the surface of MWCNTs, implying higher degree of covalent functionalization.
Fig. 9
Raman analysis of the pristine MWCNTs, MEA-, DEA- and TEA-MWCNTs, including corresponding (I D/I G) values

Consistent with FTIR results, I D/I G for the functionalized samples was greater than that of pristine MWCNTs, which means the successful functionalization of the MWCNTs. Also, the ID/IG values of functionalized samples are observed to be in sequence MEA-MWCNTs > DEA-MWCNTs > TEA-MWCNTs. Such trend is in accordance with the degree of functionalization inferred from TGA results.

Section2.Heading: Transmission electron microscopy
Section2.Para:
TEM images of pristine MWCNTs and functionalized MWCNTs (Fig. 10) show the relatively higher surface roughness of the latter. In fact, although acid washing and microwave radiation result in a high functionalization yield, these may also impose a partial damage to the graphitic structure of MWCNTs [31, 32]. Moreover, in our TEM observations, there was no evidence of adhesion between the adjacent MWCNTs. This finding suggests that contrary to the EDA [18, 19, 33], functionalization by EAs does not cause partial agglomeration/bridging of CNTs. As stated above, EAs with one amine group do not have the chance for intertube bridging between adjacent CNTs. This is consistent with relatively higher dispersibility of EA-functionalized MWCNTs than EDA-MWCNTs (Figs. 5, 6).

Section1.Heading: Conclusion
Section1.Para: In this study, three ethanolamines (MEA, DEA and TEA) were added on the surface of MWCNTs by a microwave-assisted method. The successful functionalization of these materials was confirmed by UV-vis, FTIR, TGA, Raman, TEM and dispersibility analysis. The dispersion values of EA-functionalized MWCNTs were stable in water up to one month, due to the polar nature of EAs, the significant degree of functionalization, and absence of intertube bridging. In a comparative look, MEA and then DEA are the most effective materials in terms of increasing MWCNTs dispersibility. Based upon the relatively low-cost EAs, this fast/efficient functionalization process can be a good choice for the dispersion of CNTs and other carbon nanomaterials on an industrial scale.

FormalPara.Heading: Amidation reaction
FormalPara.Para: To achieve oxidized MWCNTs (MWCNTs-COOH), pristine MWCNTs (50 mg) were added to a mixture of HNO3/H2SO4 (100 ml, 3/1 v:v) and stirred for 24 h by a magnetic stirrer at room temperature. The resultant material was neutralized by washing with abundant distilled water and filtering it through a PTFE membrane. The filter cake then washed by distilled water and dried at 50 °C for 12 h. The MWCNT-COOH was sonicated with a mixture of DMF (30 ml), DEA (15 ml) and NaNO2 (50 mg) for 10 min. This suspension was transferred into a vessel and irradiated in the microwave oven (110 °C, 700 W) for 15 min. The reaction mixture was then cooled to room temperature and filtered. The filter cake was washed several times with distilled water, followed by drying for 24 h at 50 °C.

FormalPara.Heading: Esterification reaction
FormalPara.Para: Carboxylation of MWCNTs was completed in the same manner as presented for amidation reaction. To convert the carboxyl groups into an acyl chloride (MWCNTs-COCl), carboxylated MWCNTs (50 mg) were mixed in thionyl chloride (50 ml) for 12 h by a magnetic stirrer. The reaction mixture was then cooled and filtered. The product was thoroughly washed with distilled water and dried at 50 °C for 24 h. MWNT-COCl was then sonicated with a mixture of DMF (30 ml) and DEA (15 ml) at 100 °C for 12 h. The resultant mixture was cooled and filtered. The filtration products were washed with distilled water and then dried for 24 h at 50 °C.

FormalPara.Heading: Electrophilic addition reaction
FormalPara.Para: The pristine MWNTs (50 mg) and AlCl3 (0.5 g) were mixed and ground for several minutes in an agate mortar. This mixture was then transferred into a vessel filled with a mixture of DMF (30 ml) and DEA (15 ml) and sonicated for 10 min. Two drops of concentrated hydrochloric acid were added to the suspension and the mixture was irradiated by the microwave (110 °C, 700 W) for 15 min. The reaction mixture was then cooled and filtered. The filter cake was thoroughly washed with distilled water to remove unreacted reagents, and then dried overnight at 50 °C.
